711497f-a.title: Manhattan: 18th Street (West) - 9th Avenue
711497f-a.text:
18th Street west from but not including Ninth Avenue. In the right
foreground is the Spanish Express, No. 405, with its van in front.
No. 417-27 is the Greenwich, an old apartment house, seen at the
left centre. The white two-story building beyond the Greenwich
is the new Borden offices, built about 1V26.
July 16, 1932.
P. L. Sperr.
NO REPPODUCTIONS.
R13S5

711498f-a.title: Manhattan: 18th Street (West) - 9th Avenue
711498f-a.text:
West 18th Street, east of the N.E. corner of Ninth Ave. Across ex-
cavation for the new Textile High is shown West 19th Street, east of the
N.E. corner of Ninth Ave. The rear of Nos. 340-338 West 19th Street,
(The Mark Twain Apartments) south side, between Eighth and Ninth Aves., is
shown on the right. In the background, may be seen the clock tower of
St. Peter's Protestant Episcopal Church.
September 1, 1929.
P. L. Sperr.
NO REPRODUCTIONS.

710325f-a.title: Manhattan: 9th Avenue - 18th Street
710325f-a.text:
Ninth Avenue, east side, from 18th to 17th Streets. The row of two
and three-story houses in the foreground, 124-112 Ninth Avenue, are
frame structures which will still stand in 1934.
1932.
J. Clarence Davies Collection, Museum of the City of New York,
Negative No. 176,
CREDIT LINE IMPERATIVE ON ALL REPRODUCTIONS.

710326f-a.title: Manhattan: 9th Avenue - 18th Street
710326f-a.text:
Ninth Avenue, east side, at 18th Street. The houses in this picture
from No. 112 in the right foreground to No. 128 on the N. E. cor-
ner of 18th Street are frame structures which will stand in 1934.
McParland's Malt and Hops Store, in the centre, is an interesting
product of the rapidly dying prohibition era. Stores such as this,
selling ingredlents .nd euuipment for home brewing,were legion; but
the advent of legal beer on April 7, 1933, was a blow which most of
them failed to survive.
1932.
J. Clarence Davies Collection, Museum of the City of New York.
Negative No. 165.
CREDIT LINE IMPERATIVE ON ALL REPRODUCTIONS.

711504f-a.title: Manhattan: 18th Street (West) - 9th Avenue
711504f-a.text:
Weat 18th Street, north side, east from 10th to 9th Avenues.
Adjoining the N.N. corner of 10th Aeenue are two quaint structures
No's 461-3. These are shown to better advantage in View 1. Note
that the photographer is riewing across a vacant lot at the S.E.
corner of 10th Avenue and does not show 9th Avenue.
June 14, 19S8
July 16, 1932
P.L.Sperr
NO REPRODUCTIONS

710327f-b.title: Manhattan: 9th Avenue - 18th Street (West)
710327f-b.text:
Ninth Avenue, east side, north from W. 18th Street (right,
not seen), showing a general view of this west side area with one
of its arterial transportation lines. SSeveral new apartment build-
ings are contemplated which will cause radical changes in its contour;
one such seen is at the N.E. corner of W. 20th Street. To te
right in No. 1 apoears a portion of the huge Textile High School.
This property, north of 19th Street, and extending to Eiohth
Avenue, was formerly the easterly part of the Glement C. Moore
holdings and has an interesting history. The reader can find same
in various quaint publications.
June 15, 1938.
Views 1,2 and 3
N. L. Sperr
NO REPRODUCTIONS.

711499f-a.title: Manhattan: 9th Avenue - 18th Street (West)
711499f-a.text:
West 18th Street, at, adjoining and east of the N.E. corner
of Ninth Avenue (elevated line thereon) showing prominently Textile
High extending thru the block to 19th Street. Upon this site formerly
stood P.S. 56. The photographer is viewing northeastward from a
roof top at the S.W. corner. The clearance at the right is to be
improved with a moiern 6 story apartment house (see N.Y. Times of
May 9, 1938).
June 15 1938.
Views 1 and 2
P. L. Sperr
NO REPRODUCTIONS.

711500f-a.title: Manhattan: 9th Avenue - 18th Street (West)
711500f-a.text:
404-406 est 18th Street, adjoining the S.W. corner of
Ninth avenue. The former is a two-story and the latter a three-
story frame house.
1932.
J. Clarence Davies Collection, Museum of the City of New York.
Negative No. 180

711501f-b.title: Manhattan: 9th Avenue - 18th Street (West)
711501f-b.text:

frame houses date at the latest from 1879. No. 408 is also frame

March 12, 1933.
P. L. Sperr.

711502f-a.text:

1932.
J. Clarence Davies Collection, Museum of the City of New York.

710323f-a.title: Manhattan: 9th Avenue - 18th Street
710323f-a.text:
Nos. 122 to 112 Iinth Ave., at, adjoining and south of the S.E.
corner of West 18th Street, showing a row of frame structures that
nearly occupy the entire block front from 18th to 17th Streets and
which will be demolished according to the New York Times of May 9,
1938 as a portion of planned site of a modern 6-story apartment
house. This will rise on a plot 100 x 130 feet and will include the
two 4-story brick houses Nos. 366 and 364 West 18th Street; the side
wall of one of these appearing on the extreme left of view No. 1.
Views 2 and 3 show portions of this wooden row, some of which have
brick fronts. This property has been sold by the Emigrant Industrial
Savings Bank to the 364 West 18th Street Corporation for '100,000
through Eugene J. Busher Company, who arranged a building loan of
175,000 for ten years to finance the improvement.
Views 1 \& 3:eMarch 12, 1933.
View 2:- March 7, 1929.
P. L. Sperr.
NO RDPRODUCTIONS.
